page.title:
And Onto Automated Problem Diagnosis
And Onto Automated Problem Diagnosis
page.normal_text:
Carnegie Mellon University
Carnegie Mellon University

Priya Narasimhan © November
Priya Narasimhan © November
page.enlisting:
▪ Diagnosing problems  Creates major headaches for administrators  Worsens as scale and system complexity grows ▪ Goal: automate it and get proactive  Failure detection and prediction  Problem determination (or “fingerpointing”) ▪ How: Instrumentation plus statistical analysis ▪ Diagnosing problems

page.title:
Challenges in Problem Analysis
Challenges in Problem Analysis
page.normal_text:
Carnegie Mellon University
Carnegie Mellon University

Priya Narasimhan © November
Priya Narasimhan © November
page.enlisting:
▪ Challenging in large-scale networked environment  Can have multiple failure manifestations with a single root  Can have multiple root causes for a single failure  Problems and/or their manifestations can “travel” among  A lot of information from multiple sources – what to use? ▪ Automated fingerpointing  Automatically discover faulty node in a distributed system ▪ Challenging in large-scale networked environment
▪ Challenging in large-scale networked environment ▪ C h a l l e n g i n g

Why?
Why?

Carnegie Mellon University
Carnegie Mellon University

Priya Narasimhan © November

page.title:
Goals, Non-Goals
Goals, Non-Goals
page.normal_text:
Carnegie Mellon University
Carnegie Mellon University

Priya Narasimhan © November
Priya Narasimhan © November
page.enlisting:
▪ Diagnose faulty Master/Slave node to user/admin ▪ Target production environment  Don’t instrument Hadoop or applications additionally  Use Hadoop logs as-is (white-box strategy)  Use OS-level metrics (black-box strategy) ▪ Work for various workloads and under workload changes ▪ Support online and offline diagnosis ▪ Non-goals (for now)  Tracing problem to offending line of code ▪ Diagnose faulty Master/Slave node to user/admin ▪ Target production environment
▪ Diagnose faulty Master/Slave node to user/admin ▪ D i a g n o s e

page.title:
Target Hadoop Clusters
Target Hadoop Clusters
page.enlisting:
▪ 4000-processor Yahoo!’s M45 cluster ▪ Production environment (managed by Yahoo!) ▪ Offered to CMU as free cloud-computing resource ▪ Diverse kinds of real workloads, problems in the wild ▪ Massive machine-learning, language/machine-translation ▪ Permission to harvest all logs and OS data each week ▪ 100-node Amazon’s EC2 cluster ▪ Production environment (managed by Amazon) ▪ Commercial, pay-as-you-use cloud-computing resource ▪ Workloads under our control, problems injected by us ▪ gridmix, nutch, pig, sort, randwriter ▪ Can harvest logs and OS data of only our workloads ▪ 4000-processor Yahoo!’s M45 cluster
▪ 4000-processor Yahoo!’s M45 cluster ▪ 4 0 0 0 - p r o c e s s o r

page.title:
How About Those Metrics?
How About Those Metrics?
page.enlisting:
▪ White-box metrics (from Hadoop logs)  Event-driven (based on Hadoop’s activities)  Durations  Map-task durations, Reduce-task durations, ReduceCopy-durations, etc.  System-wide dependencies between tasks and data blocks  Heartbeat information: Heartbeat rates, Heartbeat- ▪ Black-box metrics (from OS /proc)  64 different time-driven metrics (sampled every second)  Memory used, context-switch rate, User-CPU usage, ▪ White-box metrics (from Hadoop logs)  Event-driven (based on Hadoop’s activities)  Durations

page.title:
Log-Analysis Approach
Log-Analysis Approach
page.normal_text:
Carnegie Mellon University
Carnegie Mellon University
page.enlisting:
▪ SALSA: Analyzing Logs as StAte Machines [USENIX WASL 2008] ▪ Extract state-machine views of execution from Hadoop logs  Distributed control-flow view of logs  Distributed data-flow view of logs ▪ Diagnose failures based on statistics of these extracted views  Control-flow based diagnosis  Control-flow + data-flow based ▪ Perform analysis incrementally so ▪ SALSA: Analyzing Logs as StAte Machines [USENIX WASL 2008] ▪ Extract state-machine views of execution from Hadoop logs  Distributed control-flow view of logs  Distributed data-flow view of logs

page.title:
Distributed Control+Data Flow
Distributed Control+Data Flow
page.enlisting:
▪ Distributed control-flow  Causal flow of task execution across cluster nodes, i.e., ▪ Distributed data-flow  Data paths of Map outputs shuffled to Reduces  HDFS data blocks read into and written out of jobs ▪ Job-centric data-flows: Fused Control+Data Flows  Correlate paths of data and execution  Create conjoined causal paths from data source before,  Helps to trace correlated performance problems ▪ Distributed control-flow
